newsitem.title: USA: U.S. April existing home sales fell 2.4 pct.
newsitem.headline: U.S. April existing home sales fell 2.4 pct.

text.p: Sales of existing U.S. homes fell 2.4 percent in April to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 4.06 million units from a revised 4.16 million units in March, the National Association of Realtors said Tuesday.
Wall Street economists had forecast April sales of 4.09 million units.
The April sales rate was down four percent from sales of 4.23 million in April last year.
NAR reported the following details of existing home sales in seasonally adjusted annual rates:
Note--Median sales price is the midpoint where half the homes sold for more and half for less.
Note--FHLMC rate is the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp's average commitment rate for 30-year fixed-rate mortgages.
Units Sold By Region, seasonally adjusted, in 1,000s:
Median Price By Region, unadjusted, in 1,000s of dollars:
The group said the slowdown in April sales indicates that the housing market is stabilizing, rather than weakening.
"Although sales have slipped, these numbers are historically at a very high level, despite month-to-month fluctuations in the market," NAR President Russell Booth said.
The NAR forecasts that home sales will remain strong through the year because of high levels of consumer confidence in the economy and favorable home buying conditions.
